title: Oakland defense shows improvement
text:
Tom Kreager, tkreager@dnj.com 4:30 p.m. CDT October 14, 2015 Buy Photo Oakland's Turrell Ward makes a tackle against Hoover. Oakland has given up 5.0 points a game the past four weeks. (Photo: HELEN COMER/DNJ) Buy Photo 3 CONNECT 15 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
MURFREESBORO â€” An Oakland defense known for its dominance has returned to past form the past half of the season. 
The second-ranked Patriots have given up 5.0 points and 133.3 yards a game over their past four games, outscoring their opponents 166-20. 
"Really, we just go into the game with the mentality that we don't want to give up any points," said Ty Nix, an Oakland senior defensive end. "Then we have to execute our defensive coordinator's game plan and listen to what he says the entire week and trust it." 
Oakland (6-1 overall, 4-0 in Region 2-6A) will be host to Riverdale (5-2, 3-1) at 7 p.m. Friday at Ray Hughes Stadium in the Battle of the 'Boro. It marks the two schools' 47th meeting. Oakland has won the past two meetings, but trail the series 33-13. 
Oakland's defensive dominance comes despite several key graduation losses on that side of the ball, including college signees Josh Smith (linebacker), Kevin Prather (linebacker), Anthony Akers (defensive line), Tyler Black (defensive back) and Josh Cunningham (defensive back). 
Oakland first-year coach Kevin Creasy said defense has been a priority for the Patriots. 
"We pride ourselves in playing good defense," Creasy said. "That's what has put us in the position we are in now. If we hadn't played really well on defense, we'd have a whole lot more than one loss. 
"They've saved us on several occasions. We're going to rely on them heavily this week." 
Oakland has picked off 11 passes and recovered six fumbles this season. 
LSU commitment JaCoby Stevens has 39 tackles, three interceptions and recovered two fumbles. Safety Kaleb Oliver has 47 tackles and two interceptions. And linebacker Jackson Cauthen has 73 tackles and two interceptions. 
Both Oliver and Cauthen are first-year starters for the Patriots. 
"We're just taking film more seriously as a defense," Stevens. "Of course, we have Ty, Turrell Ward and Mark Pruitt as our defensive leaders. We're just listening to them." 
Nix, a three-year starter on the defensive line, has been an anchor up front. He has 28 tackles with three sacks and an interception. He moved from defensive tackle to defensive end. 
"My coaches told me in the preseason that I'd play just about every spot on the D-line this year," Nix said. "I said I was up for anything just to help the team."
